Award.AwardTitle: Directed Assembly of Colloids for Nanomanufacturing of Hierarchically Ordered Electronic Films

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The promise of polymer-based electronics is that energy harvesting, lighting and sensing applications can be achieved with cheap, flexible, lightweight and abundant plastics using faster, more efficient solution-based manufacturing. Current state-of-the-art processing for organic electronics employs toxic chlorinated organic solvents and relies on the uncontrolled self-assembly of the polymer as it solidifies from solution. Additional barriers to widespread adoption include reproducibility and lifetime issues associated with the scale-up of device manufacturing. This award aims to address these challenges through study of a novel nanomanufacturing paradigm. Water-based colloidal suspensions of electronic polymers will be assembled into hierarchical structures using external electric fields. This research will lead to cheaper, more reliable and sustainable solution-based processing of polymers for the manufacture of flexible electronics, photovoltaics and sensors. Integration of research into education will be an enduring impact of this project. Students will be involved at all levels, including undergraduates. Plans are to engage K-12 students, including minority and first-generation-to-college students, in the City of Lowell Public Schools by introducing the basics of nanotechnology and organic electronics with hands-on demonstrations and student mentoring.

The objectives of this research project are to investigate a novel dielectrophoresis (DEP) technique to manufacture hierarchically ordered conjugated polymer films from colloidal suspensions and to create a new processing paradigm for organic electronics applications. This research will provide a new nanomanufacturing method for directed assembly of multicomponent nanoparticles into well-defined structured thin films over a range of length scales. Specifically, the tasks are (i) investigate of a novel DEP technique for hierarchical patterned deposition of colloidal nanoparticles of semiconducting polymers, (ii) elucidate the role of polymer nanoparticle preparation variables on particle size, colloidal stability and internal polymer chain structures, and (iii) characterize the relationship between this new manufacturing paradigm and polymer film morphology and electronic properties. By controlling the morphology of conjugated polymer thin films, the award will study the hypothesis that films from aqueous colloidal nanoparticle assembles are more suitable for devices with improved electronic properties compared to films prepared using conventional film-casting from organic solvents. The principles learned from this fundamental research will establish design rules for conjugated polymer nanoparticle assembly and enable creation of a "colloidal process engineering tool-kit". This will serve as the underpinning of continuous nanoparticle assembly and deposition to control thin-film morphologies that can be translated into innovative and versatile manufacturing processes for electronic devices.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Polymer-based electronics offers the promise of light weight, flexible, low cost functional devices made from abundant materials. The objective of this Nanomanufacturing project was to investigate a novel dielectrophoresis (DEP) technique to manufacture hierarchically ordered conjugated polymer films from colloidal suspension.  In pursuit of this goal, research was conducted to determine the structure-processing-property relationships in aqueous suspensions of polystyrene and poly(3-hexylthiophene) (P3HT) colloids.

Intellectual Merit

The principal outcome of this research was a set of design rules for hierarchical control over the morphology of field effect transistors (FETs) on three scales. At the nano-scale, aqueous suspensions of P3HT were produced both with surfactant mini-emulsion and with graphene oxide Pickering emulsion. At the meso-scale, DEP-assisted assembly was shown to be an effective deposition technique to obtain highly oriented particle structures. On a macro-scale, DEP parameters that could prevent capillary flow to the edges of the film were identified during the dynamic drying of the films. The film morphology was quantified using a figure of merit represented by the ratio of particle chain length to electrode gap size, and the processing parameters were optimized to bridge the electrode gap. The processing-structure relationships were determined for electrode geometry (gap size), electric field characteristics (AC-voltage and frequency), and properties of colloidal suspension (particle type, particle size, volume fraction). A smaller electrode gap was favorable because it resulted in a stronger DEP force. Lower voltage was desirable in order to suppress EHD flows and electrolysis of water. The field frequency could be selected to fall between the cross-over frequencies of constituent particles of the colloidal suspension: some particles would be directed under positive DEP and others under negative DEP. Smaller colloidal particles gave better FET device performance, but did not resist hydrodynamic flows well. Higher volume fraction suspensions were preferred as the interparticle distance was reduced resulting in formation of longer chains. Drying conditions were determined for maximum packing efficiency to be: hydrophobically treated substrate, moderate relative humidity, highest DEP field strength.

Broader Impacts

The research program provided training to two Ph.D. graduate students and four undergraduates in experimental methods to produce colloidal suspensions, manipulate them using electric fields, and analyze the morphology and electronic properties of the resulting assemblies. The research was shared with the scientific community in two Ph.D. dissertations, three submitted journal articles, and two more articles in progress. The research was also presented at five technical conferences. The outcomes from this research will impact the fields of nanomanufacturing, flexible electronics and interfacial science. It will also enable greener processing of polymer coatings through replacement of toxic organic solvents in manufacturing.

Modified by: Margaret Sobkowiczkline
